deck: Alyas Palos (Alias the Eel)
description:
Origin


 
As a child in Macau Giancarlo Caranzo’s mother is killed by a thief known only as Palos “Eel,” and he vows to do anything necessary to find him and take revenge.

Taken in by his mother’s friend Alessandro he does this by training to become not just a thief and safe cracker himself, but also an acrobat and martial artists.

When he begins his career in crime tries to attract his “inspirations” attention by also taking the alias of Palos.

The new Palos however is not truly into committing crime and so only robs from villains and true thieves, seeing to it that the money gets back to the victims, as well as performing other good deeds.

Eventually he earns the name Palos on his own merits because like an eel is he is hard to catch, and if caught impossible to hold onto.

As time goes by he comes to the attention of, and joins a spy network know as Neptune, working for them he discovers the truth about the death of his mother, who his real father is, and the identity of the original Palos all of which are  far different from what he has believed since a child.

He also begins to find that what he has been told about Neptune is also a lie.

 Palos: thief/hero in the night

Created by writer Virgilio and artist Nestor Redondo in 1961 the Eel started out in the anthology komik Tagalog Klasiks in 1961 as a simple thief with a heart of gold, his run done he was replaced by other story lines such as another Virgilio / Redondo creation, masked vigilante Gagamba “Spider,” both of whom prove so popular that several movies are made about both.

Eight years later Redondo starts his own komiks company called Aries and gives the duo komiks dedicated to their adventures (a rare event for comics in the Philippines where such magazines are usually anthologies.) it’s in Palos Komiks that his story becomes more complicated. More films are made with one showing the two facing off against each other.

Running for a little less than a two years the Eel disappears again, however it seems he’s to slippery for oblivion as he has recently returned again as a super-spy in a new television series in the Philippines starting in 2008.
 
Whether his sometimes adversary Gagamba will also return remains to be seen.
name: Palos

deck: Dale Daring was a female adventurer, protagonist of her ow series in New Comics/New Adventure/Adventure Comics from 1936 to 1939. She would at times help the police in solving mysteries. At others she would have adventures in the Far East and exotic locals.
name: Dale Daring

deck: Loin of Beef was the protagonist of his own series in New Comics, debuting in 1935. He was a knight errant of the Don Quixote variety. He had a sword and armor but was evidently a below average fighter.

issue_credits.name: Captain Jim of the Texas Rangers

name: Loin of Beef

deck: Cowhide was a traveling companion to Loin of Beef. He was a big, strong man but not much of a fighter. He was a petty thief and rogue with a witty sense of humor.
name: Cowhide

deck: Billy the Kid was the protagonist of his own series in "New Comics", debuting in 1935. He had no apparent relation to the famous outlaw. He was a mischievous young boy with some mechanical skills.
name: Billy the Kid

deck: Cactus was a co-protagonist of the "Cactus and Sagebrush" series, debuting in 1935. The two of them were aging goldminers of the Old West. Cactus was short but quick to anger.

issue_credits.name: Captain Jim of the Texas Rangers

name: Cactus the goldminer

deck: Sagebrush was a co-protagonist of the "Cactus and Sagebrush" series, debuting in 1935. The two of them were aging goldminers of the Old West. Sagebrush was the taller and calmer of the two. He carried no weapons. When angered he could throw stones at his opponents and knock them out.

issue_credits.name: Captain Jim of the Texas Rangers

name: Sagebrush the goldminer

deck: Mis-Betty was a supporting character of the "Cactus and Sagebrush" series, debuting in 1935. She was a young woman and ranch owner who had befriended the two aging goldminers.
name: Mis-Betty

deck: King Harald was a character of the "Vikings" series, appearing in New Comics. He was the lover of Sigrid and father of Ivar. He sailed away on his ship and abandoned them both in the first episode.
name: King Harald

deck: Sigrid, daughter of Hagbard was the lover of King Harald and mother of Ivar. Her son was taken away and left in the wilderness to die by orders of her father.
name: Sigrid, daughter of Hagbard

deck: Theseta was a loyal servant of Hagbard and Sigrid. She helped her young mistress give birth to Ivar. She then had to abandon the boy in the wilderness to die by orders of Hagbard.
name: Theseta

deck: Ivar, son of Harald was a character of the "Vikings" series in New Comics. His birth was depicted in the first episode. He was the illegitimate son of King Harald and Sigrid. Hagbard, his maternal grandfather, had him abandoned in the wilderness to die. He was surrounded by wolves but saved by Kol the Wise. Kol recognized signs that Odin had plans for Ivar but whether they were benevolent or not was left a mystery to be determined in later episodes.

issue_credits.name: Captain Jim of the Texas Rangers

name: Ivar, son of Harald

deck: Hagbard was father to Sigrid and grandfather of Ivar. He was enraged to have an illegitimate grandson and had the boy abandoned in the wilderness to die.
name: Hagbard

deck: Kol the Wise was a Viking warrior and mystic, experienced in recognizing the signs of Odin's will. He rescued newborn Ivar by a pack of wolves and then noticed Hugin and Munin flying above them.
name: Kol the Wise

deck: J. Worthington Blimp was the titular protagonist of a comedy series, debuting in "New Comics" during 1935. He is rather obscure, mostly remembered because the series was among the earliest creations of Sheldon Mayer.
name: J. Worthington Blimp

deck: The Tinker Twins, Flea and Hooty, were the protagonists of an aborted series at "New Comics", debuting in 1935. They were students of the Penn Point military academy. Their first episode had them getting pranked by fellow students and getting in trouble. It ended in a cliff-hanger with no known resolution.
name: Tinker Twins

deck: Needles was the protagonist of a comedy strip, debuting in 1935. He was an inventor who got a diploma through a correspondence course. Apparently his lessons did not include safety measures because his first episode had him causing an explosion with his very first invention.
name: Needles

deck: He was the protagonist of a comedy strip, debuting in 1935. He was a Mexican who faced ordinary problems but offered extraordinary musings about them.

issue_credits.name: Captain Jim of the Texas Rangers

name: Chikko Chakko

deck: Freddie Bell was the child protagonist of a comic strip, debuting in 1935. He was unfailingly polite young boy. Despite his good intentions, Freddie ended up causing trouble or insulting people by failing to recognize the nature of a situation. For example mistaking a gentleman who had stuck in an open sewer hole for a beggar. He throws coins at him instead of assisting him in getting out. Naturally the genteleman feels mocked and moves to punish him.
name: Freddie Bell

deck: Wing Walker was the protagonist of an adventure series in "New Comics", debuting in 1935. He was a test pilot who lost his license under uncertain circumstances. He then found himself abducted and pressed into service by the Sons of the Red Cormorant, a criminal organization.
name: Wing Walker

deck: Captain Spinniker  was a submarine captain and protagonist of his own series. He debuted in 1935 in the pages of "New Fun Comics" but was later transfered to "New Comics" since its first issue.
name: Captain Spinniker

deck: Kendal Quick was the protagonist of an adventure series in "New Comics", debuting in 1935. He was an Elizabethan naval captain. His stories started in 1586 and apparently were all set in the late 16th century. He was a capable swordfighter.

issue_credits.name: Captain Jim of the Texas Rangers

name: Kendal Quick

deck: Marjorie Barlow was the daughter of Lord Barlow and love interest to Kendal Quick. She was beautiful but had little to no other skills.
name: Marjorie Barlow

deck: Jibby Jones was the protagonist of a comedy strip, debuting in 1935. He was a young rascal who tried to find ways of creatively interpreting his father's rules.
name: Jibby Jones

deck: Fritz the time traveler was one of of trio who traveled from the 20th century to the 19th one. He used modern songs to charm the girls of the time.
name: Fritz the time traveler

deck: Oliver Weed was one of a trio who time traveled from the 20th century to the 19th one. He advocated not using their knowledge of the future for selfish causes. Making him a source of humor for his fellows.
name: Oliver Weed

deck: Uriah Mowcher was one of a trio who time travelled from the 20th century to the 19th century. He was all in favor of using their knowledge for their own benefit and seemed rather amoral.
name: Uriah Mowcher

aliases:
Alain de Beaufort
Crusader
Iron Man
deck: Allan de Beaufort was a Crusading knight who turned up twice in Comics. First in "New Comics" #1 (1935) and secondly in "Warrior Comics" #1 (1945). He was reportedly a knight of the Fourth Crusade (1202 - 1204) who traveled the Middle East by his own means.
name: Allan de Beaufort

deck: John Coeval was husband to Mary and father to the twins Gail and Ray. He fought in World War I and was killed in 1917.
name: John Coeval

deck: Mary Coeval was wife to John Coeval and mother to the twins Gail and Ray. She died in a hospital during 1932. She made Ray promise to take care of his sister.
name: Mary Coeval

deck: Ray Coeval was the co-protagonist of the "Ray and Gail" series, debuting in 1935. He was twin brother to Gail. They were orphaned in 1932 and since then Ray acted as the head of family. He graduated highschool in 1935 but had trouble finding employment until hired as crew for a ship.
name: Ray Coeval

deck: Gail Coeval was the co-protagonist of the "Ray and Gail" series, debuting in 1935. She was the twin sister of Ray. They were orphaned in 1932 and graduated high school in 1935. She dressed and acted much as a common housewife until hired as crew for a ship.
name: Gail Coeval

deck: Willie Gewgaw was on old friend of Ray Coeval, presumably from his school days. He was assigned to find a crew for the ship of Sir Henry Ghaut and picked Ray and Gail. Willie seemed relatively well-off and owned his own car.
name: Willie Gewgaw

deck: Peter was one of the co-protagonists of the "Peter and Ho-lah-an". He was the owner and trainer of Loki and Rab.
name: Peter the Animal Trainer

deck: Loki the Ram was one of two pets of Peter. He did not particularly care for Ho-lah-an and attacked him. Peter usually rode Loki as a steed.
name: Loki the Ram

deck: Rab was one of two pets of Peter. He was taught to perform tricks and be rewarded with food.
name: Rab the Dog

deck: Ho-lah-an Morongo was a co-protagonist of the "Peter and Ho-lah-an Morongo" series. He was an "Indian Boy" who befriended Peter and taught him some new skills.
name: Ho-lah-an Morongo

deck: Utah Falcon was the protagonist of a comedy tale. The renowned hunter was reportedly invulnerable to the cold, noticing only a slight chill even when thermometers were breaking due to the fall in temperatures. However his noisy weapon was heard loud enough to wake all sleeping persons in China, thus driving all prey away. His salty tears created the Salt Lake of Utah.
name: Utah Falcon

deck: Larry was a co-protagonist of the "Castaway Island" series, debuting in 1936. He was a young sailor who sailed the Pacific Ocean. When the rest of the crew abandoned their ship during a storm, Larry was unconscious and failed to follow them. He led the abandoned ship to a desert island and survived there with his companion Dot.

issue_credits.name: Captain Jim of the Texas Rangers

name: Larry of Castaway Island

deck: Dot was a co-protagonist of the "Castaway Island" series, debuting in 1936.She was daughter to a ship owner and followed him in sailing  the Pacific Ocean. When the crew abandoned their ship during a storm, Dot failed to follow them. She and forgotten crew member Larry survived in a desert island.

issue_credits.name: Captain Jim of the Texas Rangers

name: Dot of Castaway Island

aliases: Captain Jim of the Texas Rangers (rename)
deck: Captain Bill of the Rangers was the protagonist of a Western series, debuting in 1936. He solved various crime mysteries.

issue_credits.name: Captain Jim of the Texas Rangers

name: Captain Bill of the Rangers

deck: Jane and Johnny were siblings visiting the ranch of their Uncle Bob. They were key witnesses of a train robbery and helped Captain Bill track down the suspects.
name: Jane and Johnny

deck: Dare-Devil Dunk was the protagonist of a comedy series, debuting in 1936. He was a young man seeking employment as a "death-defying stunt man".
name: Dare-Devil Dunk

deck: Drizzle was the manager of Dare-Devil Dunk.
name: Drizzle

deck: Beany the dreamer was the protagonist of a comedy series, debuting in 1936. He was a schoolboy who had surreal dreams at night.
name: Beany the dreamer

deck: Steve Carson was the protagonist of the "Federal Men" series, debuting in 1936. He was an FBI agent who would investigate various cases, solo or with others. He was an expert marksman and master of disguise.
description: Steve Carson was among the early creations of Joe Shuester and Jerry Siegel.

issue_credits.name: Adventure of the Ring of Hijackers
The Menace of the Invisible Raiders
The Case of the Camera Curse
The Mystery of the Undersea Terror
The Mystery of the Men with the Staring Eyes
The Adventure of the Earthquake Terror
The Wax-Double Killers/The Thought Machine Of Fang Gow/The Return of Singapore Sal/The Pawn Broker/The Phony Trucking Business/The Nastonian Agent/ At Grips With The Wolf MenS
Captain Jim of the Texas Rangers

name: Steve Carson

volume_credits.name: DC Comics: Sixty Years of the World’s Favorite Comic Book Heroes

deck: Lady Lynette is a character of Arthurian legend, adapted to comic books. She was the sister of Lyonesse, captive of the Red Knight. Lynette comes to Camelot to seek help. Failing to make the importance of her case clear, Lynette ends up with only Gareth volunteering to help. At the time the youth being not a knight but kitchen servant.
description:
Lynette keeps insulting Gareth through their travel. This does not stop him from defeating the Red Knight, rescuing Lyonesse and earning his knighthood. Gareth proceeds to marry Lyonesse while Lynette marries Gaheris, a brother of Gareth.

The tale has been adapted to modern literature with some differences. For example the poem "Gareth and Lynette" by Alfred Tennyson makes Gareth indifferent to the charms of Lyonesse. He instead wants to woo and marry Lynette.
name: Lady Lynette

aliases:
Beaumains
Fair Hands
Good Hands
White Hands
deck: Gareth is one of the Knights of the Round Table from Medieval legend. He is the youngest son of King Lot of Orkney and Morgause, half-sister to King Arthur. He is thus a brother to Gawain, Agravaine, Gaheris, and half-brother of Mordred. He reportedly served as a kitchen servant until earning his knighthood. He was later killed while trying to prevent Lancelot, his mentor, to escape Camelot with Guinevere.
name: Sir Gareth

volume_credits.name: Arthur & Lancelot: The Fight for Camelot

deck: Inch is a comedy protagonist, debuting in 1936. He is a little boy trying to make some money. In his first appearance he and his gang capture all the cats in their neighborhood. They are then trying to sell the cats for ten cents each.
name: Inch

deck: Pincus is the only named supporting character of Inch in their first appearance. He is the only black member of the kid gang and the one who catches most of the cats.
name: Pincus

deck: Jarvis Lorry is a character from the novel "A Tale of Two Cities" (1859) by Charles Dickens. He is an employee of Tellson's Bank who sets the events in motion by revealing to Lucie Manette that her father is not dead. He then takes her to France to help rescue Dr. Alexandre Manette.
name: Jarvis Lorry

deck: Lucie Manette is the main female character of the novel "A Tale of Two Cities" (1859) by Charles Dickens. She was born c. 1757 in France but moved to Great Britain as an infant. In 1775 she learned her father Dr. Alexandre Manette was imprisoned in France and set out to rescue him.

issue_credits.name: Captain Jim of the Texas Rangers

name: Lucie Manette

deck: Ernest Defarge is a character from the novel "A Tale of Two Cities" by Charles Dickens. He is a former servant and proud owner  of a Paris wine shop. He is also secretly working with a group of revolutionaries, preparing the French Revolution.
name: Ernest Defarge

deck: Therese Defarge is a character from the novel "A Tale of Two Cities" (1859) by Charles Dickens. Madame Defarge is always almost depicted knitting. However her knitting includes coded messages. She is agent of Revolution in France.
description:
Therese lost her father, sister and brother-in-law when she was a young girl. They all died due to decisions by the noble and ruthless family of the Evrèmondes. In adulthood Therese works fervently to bring death to all descendants of the Evrèmondes, regardless of how innocent they are of past crimes. She also takes pride in the execution of other French noblemen.

Because Defarge knitting tends to mean someone is about to meet his doom, the character may be inspired by the three Fates.
name: Therese Defarge

aliases:
Ol' Oz Bopp
Old Oz Bopp
deck: Oz Bopp was the protagonist of a comedy strip, debuting in 1936. He was an aging police official who tried to keep order in his town but had some misadventures.

issue_credits.name: Captain Jim of the Texas Rangers

name: Oz Bopp

deck: Jungle Boy was the titular character of an aborted series, debuting in 1936. He was a little white boy living in the African Jungle. He is supposed to be lucky. Surviving an encounter with a hungry lion possibly confirms it. His story ended in a cliffhanger.
name: Jungle Boy

deck: Bombah is the best and only friend of the Jungle Boy. He was attacked by a lion while playing but rescued by Par-Nak, his older brother.
name: Bombah

deck: Par-Nak is the older brother of Bombah. He is an African warrior. In his brief appearance, Par-Nak was able to spear a lion, sidestep its attack, wrestle it and cut its throat with a knife. He was then about to be attacked by a leopard, the story ending in a cliffhanger.
name: Par-Nak

deck: Tex the Cowboy was a co-protagonist of the "Slim and Tex" series, debuting in 1936. He was too shy to ask Miss Helen, his love interest, to the local dance and send Slim to ask her for him. When Helen chose Slim as her dance partner, shy Tex knocked his pal to the ground.
name: Tex the Cowboy

deck: Slim the Cowboy was a co-protagonist of the "Slim and Tex" series, debuting in 1936. He was too shy to ask Miss Helen, their love interest, to the dance. He lost a coin toss which obligated him to ask her on behalf of Tex. Instead Helen picked him as her dance partner. Slim went out to face his enraged friend.
name: Slim the Cowboy

deck: Miss Helen was a single woman in the Old West. She was the love interest of Slim and Tex who were both too shy to ask her to the local dance. She picked Slim because he actually was brave enough to come to her house.
name: Miss Helen

deck: Andy Handy was the protagonist of a comedy strip, debuting in 1936. He was incapable of performing seemingly simple chores without breaking objects.

issue_credits.name: Captain Jim of the Texas Rangers

name: Andy Handy

deck: Maginnis was an officer of the Canadian Mounted Police who undertook various missions, both in uniform and undercover.

issue_credits.name: Captain Jim of the Texas Rangers

name: Maginnis

deck: Major Hall was the direct superior of Maginnis in the Canadian Mounted Police.
name: Major Hall

deck: Bugville was a strip focusing not on any particular characters but to a whole city of bugs.
name: Bugville

deck: Bill Brown was the protagonist of a humorous tale appearing in 1936. He was an office worker. He was fed up with his wife insisting on using all his free time joining her in playing bridge with their  friends. Unfortunately his wife's fists were convincing enough for him to shut up and prepare for another night of bridge.
name: Bill Brown
